docs.lead_paragraph: Both companies are in Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings, but there is a tale of two Christmases at Malden Mills, the textile factory in Lawrence, Mass., and Polaroid, the photography company in Cambridge, Mass. Malden's chief executive, Aaron M. Feuerstein, became a national hero when he paid idled workers and rebuilt his plant after a Christmas-season fire devastated his mill six years ago. On Christmas Eve this year, Mr. Feuerstein received a standing ovation from 700 employees at a rally at the mill to kick off his ''Polartec Promise'' campaign, which urges consumers to buy products made from Polartec, Malden's trademark synthetic fleece fabric. ''I am doing all I can for our company and our people,'' he said on Friday.

headline.main: Private Sector; Bankruptcy Court Fault Lines Between the Good and the Bad

docs.abstract: Malden Mills chief executive, Aaron M Feuerstein, is hailed for looking after his employees idled by devastating mill fire, while another company in Chapter 11, Polaroid, is reviled for scrapping health benefits for 6,000 retired employees even as it seeks to award executives $19 million in bonuses; photo (M)

byline.original: By Lynnley Browning (COMPILED BY RICK GLADSTONE)

docs.lead_paragraph: President Bush said today in his weekly radio address that his first year in office was ending with progress on foreign battlefields and accomplishments at home, but he said the coming year ''will require our sustained commitment to the war against terrorism.'' ''We cannot know how long this struggle will last,'' he added.

headline.main: At First Year's End, Bush Cites Both Victories and Challenges

docs.abstract: Pres Bush uses weekly radio address to appraise his first year in office and to assert that coming year will require sustained commitment to war against terrorism (M)
docs.snippet: President Bush said today in his weekly radio address that his first year in office was ending with progress on foreign battlefields and accomplishments at home, but he said the coming year ''will require our sustained commitment to the war against...

docs.lead_paragraph: TO many, the idea that neuroses or depression could be diagnosed as precisely or treated as effectively as a broken leg or a burst appendix seems counterintuitive, even preposterous. To the layperson, symptoms of psychological ills often seem vaguer, more diffuse than physiological ones. Diagnoses seem more subjective, and many people suspect that a patient has more control over a mental illness than a physical one. But the medical model of mental illness has gained ground in recent years as scientists discover biological, chemical and even genetic explanations for mental disorders. With these discoveries have come a citizens' movement for equivalence, or parity, in the insurance coverage of mental and physical illnesses.
docs.abstract: Citizens' movement for parity in insurance coverage of mental and physical illnesses has been spurred by discovery in recent years of biological, chemical and even genetic explanations for mental disorders; psychiatrists resent managed care even more than most other doctors, but parity would be unaffordable without cost-control techniques of managed care; House Republicans promise to hold hearings on parity proposals next year, even though all agree that parity is no panacea; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Families of Victims Fault Benefits Plan of Insurance Giant'' (front page, Dec. 26): As medical care has become increasingly expensive, the cost to businesses of providing benefits is reaching unsustainable levels. Many can no longer afford to provide benefits at all, or have passed on more of the direct cost to employees. And there can be expensive disruptions in benefits when one leaves a job.
docs.abstract: Letter from Dr Alison Fulmer on most insured Americans are in same situation as families of World Trade Center victims: just a pink slip or death away from loss of health benefits (Dec 26 article)

docs.lead_paragraph: IN 1968, during the Vietnam War, President Lyndon B. Johnson decided that America had to spend its money on the military rather than his domestic agenda, the Great Society. ''That bitch of a war,'' Johnson lamented toward the end of his life, ''killed the lady I really loved -- the Great Society.'' As America prepares to enter the next stage of the war and President Bush plans to make homeland security the centerpiece of his fiscal 2003 budget when Congress reconvenes in January, many citizens are convinced that politicians will again make a similar trade-off. Commentators have predicted that there will not be any new government programs that serve a need other than war. Reflecting this fear, Professor Laura D. Tyson, former chief economic adviser to President Clinton, wrote, ''Guns versus butter is elementary economics: a society that chooses to spend more of its resources on defense and security will have less available for things like education, health, retirement security, productive investment and consumption.''

headline.main: The Nation: Guns and Butter; Government Can Run More Than a War

docs.abstract: Article by Julian E Zelizer, history professor, discounts concern that Pres Bush's plans to make homeland security centerpiece of his fiscal 2003 budget will preclude increased spending on domestic programs; says American history reveals that throughout 20th century, domestic programs have been created during nation's most heated wars; says guns and butter often go hand-in-hand; says military crises have exposed areas where federal government was needed and have generated broad public support in country suspicious of government; says given multiple fronts on which war on terrorism is being waged, new federal programs may well be created that deal with medical research, health care, food safety, computer technology, law enforcement, unemployment insurance, transportation, energy production and education; photo (M)
docs.snippet: IN 1968, during the Vietnam War, President Lyndon B. Johnson decided that America had to spend its money on the military rather than his domestic agenda, the Great Society. ''That bitch of a war,'' Johnson lamented toward the end of his life,...

docs.lead_paragraph: Every day the memorials continue, as they should, for the dead of Sept. 11. This article is not about those memories. It's about other lives that ended in the year 2001, lives that ended as many of them were lived: without fanfare, without headlines in the local paper, let alone the national press.
docs.abstract: Article profiles Long Islanders who died in past year and who changed Island for better in variety of ways: Teresa Kennedy, who helped found home for homeless and unwed pregnant teens, longtime civil rights activist James Davis, Brookhaven tax receiver, mortician and funeral home owner F Daniel Moloney, former Long Beach Police Comr Thomas Browne, cardiologist Robert Rubino, Suffolk County legislator Millie Steinberg who helped victims of domestic violence and sexual assault, Long Island Historical Journal founder Roger Wunderlich, former Museums at Stony Brook director Susan Stitt, former Lloyd Harbor mayor and environmentalist Richardson Pratt Jr, arborist and entomologist Charles Edgar Whitmore, State University of New York College of Engineering and Applied Sciences founder Thomas F Irvine, Environmental Defense Fund co-founder Dennis Puleston, Hispanic leader Paul Irizarry, Spanish-born painter Esteban Vicente, Montauk Point Lighthouse savior Giorgina Reid, newspaper publisher Robert Richner and Nassau County attorney Joseph Jaspan; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: MANY out-of-towners still appear to be steering clear of New York -- hotel vacancies remain up, theater attendance down -- but what about those who have no choice, the stalwart, working masses who must venture there every day? While city dwellers gradually adjust to life after Sept. 11, residents of Connecticut's suburbs continue to grapple with a different set of pressures. People throughout the country remain apprehensive about boarding planes, but many commuters here and their families are nervous about simply going to work.
docs.abstract: Many Connecticut commuters and their families, skittish after September 11 terrorist attacks, are anxious about going to work in Manhattan; many suburban mental-health professionals report heavier case loads and that people, particularly children, are finding that added stress has become part of their everyday lives; experts say children may become less attentive to schoolwork, irritable and easily distracted and may develop physiological symptoms such as headaches or stomachaches; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: ''The more intense the craze, the higher the type of intellect that succumbs to it.'' Benjamin Anderson, ''Economics and the Public Welfare,'' 1949 THE year just ending has been painful for most investors. It has probably hurt even more for some big names who achieved fame on Wall Street for being a bit smarter than the average guy.

headline.main: Even the Smartest Money Can Slip Up

docs.abstract: Many of world's richest people lost hundreds of millions, even billions, of dollars in investments during 2001; energy sector and telecommunications companies provided most of losses, some to famous investors whose pain and humiliation came under public view; money managers say their billionaire and centimillionaire clients were excessively speculative with their investments; photos; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Your Dec. 26 front-page article about the difficulties the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has had unraveling the anthrax outbreak raises important questions about public health in the United States. Organizations like the Department of Health and Human Services, the C.D.C. and even the American Medical Association should have taken the reins decades ago to coordinate communication among doctors. They have failed to do so.
docs.abstract: Dr Paul Starr letter on difficulty unraveling anthrax outbreak says US health authorities should have taken reins decades ago to coordinate communication among doctors (S)
